DOCNAME: CASE OF LUEDICKE, BELKACEM AND KOÇ v. GERMANY
CONCLUSION: Preliminary objection rejected (disappearance of object of proceedings);Violation of Art. 6-3-e;Not necessary to examine Art. 14;Pecuniary damage - financial award;Just satisfaction partially reserved
TEXT: CARDINAL . At the time when they introduced their applications with the ORG , Mr. PERSON , Mr. PERSON and Mr. PERSON were resident in GPE .

The CARDINAL applicants were charged before the NORP courts with the commission of various criminal offences . Since they were not sufficiently familiar with the language of the country , they were assisted by an interpreter in accordance with NORP law . After conviction , they were ordered , amongst other things , to pay the costs of the proceedings , including the interpretation costs . They consider that the inclusion of this latter item is contrary to , inter alia , Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW .

CARDINAL . In criminal proceedings , the courts must use the services of an interpreter whenever the accused is not conversant with NORP . The first sentence of section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of the LAW of LAW ( Gerichtsverfassungsgesetz ) provides as follows :
" If the proceedings before the court involve the participation of persons who do not have command of the NORP language , an interpreter shall be employed . "

Pursuant to this provision , the assistance of an interpreter is made available as a matter of course to an accused - whatever his nationality - who does not understand or speak the NORP language . The same rule is applicable to the examination of witnesses who do not have command of the NORP language .

The obligation to employ an interpreter is , however , subject to CARDINAL exception , namely when all the participants are familiar with the foreign language ( section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of the LAW of LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Interpretation costs are part of the costs of the proceedings which , according to LAW , first sentence , of LAW ( GPE ) , are made up of " the fees ( GPE ) and expenses of the ORG " . The latter are listed in LAW ( PERSON ) which in turn refers to the Witnesses and Experts ( Expenses ) Act ( PERSON über die Entschädigung PERSON ) . Section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of the last - mentioned LAW provides that " for the purposes of compensation , interpreters shall be treated as experts " .
According to LAW para . CARDINAL , first sentence , of LAW :
" The accused shall bear the costs of such part of the proceedings as concerned the act that gave rise to the conviction ... "

Under this provision , the question of payment of the costs of the proceedings arises only after there has been a final ruling on the guilt of the accused ; an accused person may never be required to make any advance payment on these costs . In the event of acquittal or of proceedings being discontinued , the ORG in principle bears the costs . On the other hand , if the individual concerned is convicted , he has to pay the costs , but only such proportion thereof as relates to the criminal charges upheld by the court .

CARDINAL . As concerns interpretation costs in particular , Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW , which forms an integral part of the domestic law , specifies that " everyone charged with a criminal offence has the ( right ) ... to have the free assistance of an interpreter if he can not understand or speak the language used in court " . This text has not been interpreted and applied by the NORP courts in a uniform way . Certain courts read it as embodying an obligation for the ORG to bear the costs in question for all time and in all cases ; other courts , including some higher courts , consider on the contrary that while Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) - like LAW - exempts an accused ( that is , a person " charged with a criminal offence " ) from paying in advance for the expenses incurred by the use of an interpreter , it does not prohibit such expenses being awarded against a convicted person .

CARDINAL . Interpretation costs are assessed in accordance with a scale fixed by law and not by the interpreters themselves ; the assessment is made by a court official ( PERSON ) when the overall costs of the proceedings are determined .
CARDINAL . Mr. PERSON is a citizen of GPE and was , at the time of his application to the Commission , a member of the NORP Forces stationed in GPE .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE , ORG ( ORG ) convicted him of a road traffic offence . He was fined ORG and ordered to pay the costs of the proceedings .

On DATE , after the judgment had become final , the public prosecutor ’s department ( ORG ) attached to ORG ( Landgericht ) served Mr. Luedicke with a notice to pay the sum of DM CARDINAL , made up of the fine of ORG and the fees ( GPE ) due in respect of the criminal proceedings ( DM CARDINAL ) and the withdrawal of his driving licence ( DM CARDINAL ) , together with police costs ( DM CARDINAL ) and interpretation costs ( DM CARDINAL ) . DM CARDINAL of the last item related to the oral hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE , the applicant , represented by ORG at GPE , entered an appeal ( GPE ) against this assessment of costs ; he maintained that the assessment was contrary to LAW CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW in so far as it concerned payment of the interpretation costs .
Following the refusal of the auditor ( PERSON ) attached to ORG to modify the assessment , the matter was referred to ORG which dismissed the appeal on DATE . ORG stated in particular :

" The object of LAW ... is to guarantee certain fundamental rights to everyone faced with criminal proceedings . In GPE , this LAW ) applies to proceedings brought against foreigners as well as to those brought against NORP nationals . It is not the aim of the provision to place foreigners in a more favourable position than NORP nationals . This , however , would be the case if a foreign convicted person was not required to pay the interpretation costs . For example , under the NORP law of procedure and costs , a deaf - and - dumb convicted person against whom proceedings can not be taken without a special interpreter must pay the costs of interpretation . So must also a NORP convicted person in whose trial non - NORP - speaking witnesses have to be examined with the assistance of an interpreter . Under the rules of NORP criminal procedure every person finally convicted must himself bear all the costs of the proceedings , including ... the interpretation expenses . This obligation is not contrary to LAW ... which does not forbid awarding the costs of the proceedings against a person convicted of an offence .

Under NORP procedural law , however , no accused person need make advance payment for the costs of interpreters ... This would appear not to be the case in other signatory GPE of the Convention as otherwise it would be difficult to understand the wording of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) .
The ORG thus interprets Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) ... as a provisional exemption from paying the interpretation costs ... "

CARDINAL . On DATE , following an " immediate appeal " ( sofortige Beschwerde ) by Mr. PERSON , ORG confirmed the impugned decision , relying , inter alia , on the " correctness of the reasoning " contained in that decision .
On DATE , the applicant paid the costs of the proceedings , including the interpretation costs .
CARDINAL . Mr. PERSON is an NORP citizen , born in DATE . After completing his apprenticeship as a locksmith in GPE , he rejoined his father in GPE where he followed various occupations .

He was charged with robbery and with assault occasioning bodily harm ; his case was tried by ORG ( PERSON ) . On DATE , ORG convicted him of assault occasioning bodily harm . He was sentenced to CARDINAL GPE imprisonment ( ORG ) - a sentence deemed to have been served during his detention on remand - and to a fine of DM CARDINAL , and he was ordered to pay the costs of the proceedings .

CARDINAL . On DATE , Mr. PERSON filed an " immediate appeal " against the order as to costs insofar as the interpretation costs had been included in the award . He submitted that Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW granted him exemption from payment of the costs in question .

On DATE , ORG dismissed the appeal . ORG reasoned that , since no assessment of costs had yet been made , there had been no decision capable of being challenged on appeal . ORG further stated that ORG would have acted improperly if it had omitted the interpretation costs from its decision on the costs of the proceedings - the former costs , according to LAW read in conjunction with LAW and the Witnesses and Experts ( LAW , constituting a component of the latter costs . Furthermore , it was added , Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW did not prohibit a convicted person being made to bear interpretation costs .

The latter sum comprised the expenses incurred in respect of Mr. PERSON ’s appearance before the judge on DATE ( DM CARDINAL ) , the review on DATE of his detention on remand ( NORP ) ( DM CARDINAL ) , the translation of the indictment ( DM CARDINAL ) and the trial hearing on DATE ( DM CARDINAL ) .

The applicant unsuccessfully challenged the inclusion of interpretation costs in this assessment of the costs . On CARDINAL DATE , his appeal was dismissed by ORG which held , inter alia , that Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) of the LAW did not prevent interpretation costs being awarded against a convicted person . Mr. PERSON then lodged an " immediate appeal " which was rejected by ORG on DATE . As far as Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) was concerned , ORG referred to its decision of CARDINAL DATE and continued :

" In the light of the context of Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL ) ... , which lays down fundamental guarantees for a fair trial , ORG ... interprets sub - paragraph ( e ) ( article DATE ) to mean that the assistance of an interpreter must not be made dependent on the accused ’s making any advance payment . This sub - paragraph guarantees a court hearing for a foreigner who is ignorant of the language , regardless of his capacity to pay .

Who finally has to bear the costs of interpretation after the proceedings have terminated is a different question . That after conviction this may be the accused is not excluded by LAW CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) ... "

CARDINAL . On DATE , following a request by Mr. PERSON , ORG allowed him to defer payment " until the decision of ORG be known " . From that time , he has not been required to pay the costs in question since , at the request of the Government , the relevant GPE authorities ( ORG ) have suspended recovery awaiting the judgment of this ORG .

CARDINAL . Mr. PERSON , a NORP citizen born in DATE , has been employed in GPE in various trades , including mining and the construction industry . When he applied to the Commission , he was living at FAC . On DATE , he notified the relevant authorities in ORG , near GPE , his last place of residence in GPE , of his intention to return to GPE .

CARDINAL . On DATE , ORG attached to ORG ( ORG beim ORG ) at GPE convicted Mr. PERSON of causing grievous bodily harm . He was sentenced to a DATE ’s imprisonment , but the balance of his sentence remaining after allowance had been made for his detention on remand was commuted to a period of probation . The court ordered the applicant to bear the costs of the proceedings " with the exception , however , of the costs occasioned by the assistance of the LANGUAGE - language interpreter , which costs are to be borne by the ORG " . Although taking notice of the conflicting practice of the NORP courts in this connection , ORG held that the " free " assistance of an interpreter , as guaranteed by Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ( article DATE ) to every accused not conversant with the language of the court , is to be understood as being free once and for all time .

CARDINAL . On an " immediate appeal " by the public prosecutor ’s department , ORG ( Oberlandesgericht ) , in a fully reasoned decision delivered on DATE , set aside ORG judgment insofar as it related to the interpretation costs . ORG stated :

" On [ its ] wording , it is controversial whether ( Article CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ( e ) ) ( article DATE ) forbids a convicted person ’s being charged with the costs of interpretation under the above - cited provisions relating to costs or whether - in the case of criminal proceedings in NORP courts DATE it merely means that the assistance of an interpreter may not be made dependent on an advance payment by the accused . ...

The object of the ORG is to secure human rights and fundamental freedoms against arbitrary ORG action and to place them under the protection of supranational law . ... It is not its purpose to go further and alter the national legal systems ... The list of procedural guarantees in DATE ( article CARDINAL ) of the LAW shows that the intention was to enshrine rights of the citizen and duties of the ORG which ensure a fair trial . This obviously means that the accused ( or person charged ) should be able to call for the assistance of an interpreter if he does not understand or speak the language used in court and that such assistance should be in no way dependent on the question of costs . But it certainly does not mean that even a convicted person may not have the costs of interpretation awarded against him . A fair trial is guaranteed in this respect insofar as the accused must be assisted by the interpreter he needs . The question whether he may later be required to bear the costs is not of the same order as the problem of guaranteeing human rights and fundamental freedoms but , both in theoretical and practical terms , is of lesser moment . It can not be assumed that the ORG is intended to provide a piecemeal solution of the question of costs in criminal proceedings . Nor does the consideration that a foreigner should not receive worse treatment in the matter of costs than a national , dictate the conclusion that permanent exemption from costs is necessarily implied by the object of LAW The Convention would not have come appreciably nearer to achieving its aim by prohibiting a financial disadvantage of such a kind . "
On DATE , Mr. PERSON applied to ORG ( Bundesverfassungsgericht ) which , DATE , declined to hear the application on the ground that it did not offer sufficient prospects of success .
